body: Tentatively slated for 5.6 M1 for _team discussion_
**Team Decision:** Add to general backlog to await further interest from the community.
Just hit this as well. Working around it in a manner similar to @sewe.

issue.title: Not able to create multiple @TempDir in a testcase

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
JUnit annotation @TempDir does not create multiple temporary directories. After initialization of two or more variables annotated with @TempDir all of them hold one and the same reference to a temporary path in the filesystem â€“ actually only one temporary diectory has been created.

## Steps to reproduce

Just implement a sample code snippet as follwing (no difference between non-private field in a test class or a parameter in a lifecycle method):

Example 1:
public class MyTest {
@TempDir
Path one;

@TempDir
Path two;
...
}

Example 2:
@Test
public void myTest(@TempDir Path one, @TempDir Path two) {...}

## Context
- Used versions (Jupiter/Vintage/Platform):
<dependency>
	<groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
	<artifactId>junit-jupiter-api</artifactId>
	<version>5.5.2</version>
	<scope>test</scope>
</dependency>
<dependency>
	<groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
	<artifactId>junit-jupiter-engine</artifactId>
	<version>5.5.2</version>
	<scope>test</scope>
</dependency>
 - Used versions (Jupiter/Vintage/Platform):

 - Build Tool/IDE:
Apache Maven 3.6.0
Spring Tool Suite 4.4.0.RELEASE (Eclipse)

## Deliverables

- [ ] ...

body:
@sormuras 
Thank you very much for the quick reply in #2029 â€“ sorry, i missed this one.
What is the actual reason for not creating multiple folders?
The workaround `Files.createDirectories(temp.resolve("one"));` applies to my issue, but is IMHO not really straightforward compared to just create muliple folders as the code suggests.
Is this issue up for grabs? If so I'd like to give it a try.
@jkosh44 Before starting work, we need to decide if/how we want to support it.

> Is this issue up for grabs?

No. Its state is: "waiting for interest" -- which seem to raise lately.

fwiw, I'm still in favor to add a "generic resource manager extension" to Jupiter, like outlined here: https://github.com/sormuras/brahms#resource-manager-extension
@sewe that would be a breaking change to a common use-case.
